summary: Astrocytoma is a type of brain tumor originating from star-shaped glial cells called astrocytes, primarily in the cerebrum, and occasionally in the spinal cord. It is the second most common glioma and typically does not spread outside the central nervous system. Astrocytomas are graded from I to IV based on malignancy, with low-grade types often found in children and young adults, and high-grade types more prevalent in adults.
causes: Homozygous deletion of CDKN2A/B (main feature of high-grade astrocytoma)
Genome-wide pattern of DNA copy-number alterations (CNAs)
risk_factors: Childhood or young adulthood (for low-grade types)
Young people (for astrocytomas in the base of the brain)
symptoms: Headache that goes away after vomiting
diagnosis: Tests of vision, balance, coordination, and mental status
Neuropathologist examination (for atypical cells, new blood vessel growth, mitotic figures)
subtypes: Subependymal giant cell astrocytoma (WHO Grade I)
